S5.T1.caption: Table 1. Results showing the centralised and local accuracy on Reddit. The Accc​e​n​t(%)Acc_{cent}(\%) value refers to the accuracy of the federated model on the centralised test set. In contrast, Avgl​o​c(%)Avg_{loc}(\%), Bl​o​c(%)B_{loc}(\%), and Wl​o​c(%)W_{loc}(\%) refer to the average accuracy of the model on the local test sets of the whole population, the top 10%percent1010\% of clients in terms of local accuracy and the worst 10%percent1010\% respectively. The (V​a​rA​v​g)𝑉𝑎subscript𝑟𝐴𝑣𝑔(Var_{Avg}), (V​a​rB)𝑉𝑎subscript𝑟𝐵(Var_{B}), and (V​a​rW)𝑉𝑎subscript𝑟𝑊(Var_{W}) values refer to the variance in accuracy seen by the populations above. While fairness does decrease variance at q≥1.0𝑞1.0q\geq 1.0, the harm to accuracy is too great compared to q=0.1𝑞0.1q=0.1. The proposed HK​Dsubscript𝐻𝐾𝐷H_{KD} model improves accuracy across clients but increases variance for everyone except the worst performers.

references: We begin by examining the convergence process for next-word prediction on Reddit and summarise our findings on the centralised test-set accuracy and local accuracy. As shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1, the impact of q-FFL on accuracy is neutral to negative for our tested q𝑞q-values, while that of TERM is highly negative for all tested t𝑡t. Although fairness reliably reduces the accuracy variance for q≥1𝑞1q\geq 1, the performance cost is too high for all values reported in Section 4.1. Meanwhile, we found that TERM did not obtain acceptable performance for any (t) we explored and excluded it from future Reddit experiments.

S5.T2.caption: Table 2. Results for FEMNIST. Unlike Reddit, there did not seem to be a clear proportional relation between accuracy and fairness level for our tested parameters; as such, we chose to report the best and “fairest” value. Furthermore, using KD helps the best performers primarily; however, both HK​Dsubscript𝐻𝐾𝐷H_{KD} and HE​W​Csubscript𝐻𝐸𝑊𝐶H_{EWC} do well.

references: We begin by examining the convergence process for next-word prediction on Reddit and summarise our findings on the centralised test-set accuracy and local accuracy. As shown in
, the impact of q-FFL on accuracy is neutral to negative for our tested
-values, while that of TERM is highly negative for all tested
. Although fairness reliably reduces the accuracy variance for
, the performance cost is too high for all values reported in
. Meanwhile, we found that TERM did not obtain acceptable performance for any (t) we explored and excluded it from future Reddit experiments.
Moving on to the FEMNIST training results,
show that q-FedAvg and PaFL both tend to cause instability for our hyperparameters. However, both q-FedAvg with
have a comparable centralised and average local accuracy to FedAvg. Unlike Reddit, TERM is well-behaved at a value of
and thus included in future experiments.
indicates the CIFAR-10 image classification task to be more resilient to fairness than previous tasks, with a noticeable accuracy decrease only observable for
. The lower sensitivity of this task to FFL is consistent with
who find CIFAR-10 highly resilient to robust

. Due to the similarity across fairness levels, the convergence graph for CIFAR-10 is not shown. Given this lesser sensitivity for our tested values, we chose not to expand the CIFAR-10 experiments past q-FedAvg and
. These findings indicate that the dataset heterogeneity may need to be meaningful rather than artificially imposed for significant effects to emerge.

The loss-based averaging mechanism of q-FedAvg and TERM is not guaranteed to improve the final accuracy distribution proportionally to the fairness parameter and may fail to do so under our specific experimental conditions. This calls for further inquiry into the viability of such methods.

S5.T4.caption: Table 4. Results showing the relative accuracy of FFL and PaFL models on Reddit, %<0\%<0 refers to the number of clients with negative relative accuracy. The best value in a column is bold, while the best in a group is underlined. The chosen optimal fair model does not significantly reduce the number of underperforming clients in our experiments. Alternatively, HK​Dsubscript𝐻𝐾𝐷H_{KD} lowers it to half. Local adaptation always provides similar results for the chosen hyperparameters.

references: Having established baselines of accuracy for fair models, we can now evaluate the relative accuracy of FFL, PaFL and their interactions with local adaptation. Unfortunately, the CIFAR-10 data is uninformative as the federated model outperforms the local one for all clients, consistent with the findings of
For q-FFL, the results for the language task showcased in

are less than satisfactory as fair models fail to provide benefits in terms of the number of underperforming clients, relative accuracy, or variance. Furthermore, fair models do not offer an improvement over FedAvg once adapted—this is directly visible in the
scatter plot of relative accuracy against local model accuracy.
The results for image recognition on FEMNIST are more unusual yet similarly discouraging for both q-FFL and TERM.
makes it clear that the fair model achieves a higher relative accuracy on average and amongst the top
of clients at the cost of obtaining a

. Additionally, it has over twice as many underperforming clients with negative relative accuracies. We speculate that focusing on clients with high losses harms the accuracy of fair models on those capable of training high-quality local models. This result is corroborated by the final distribution shown in

the underperforming clients have high local model accuracy. Another factor to consider is the atypical personalisation behaviour of FEMNIST. Models trained with FedAvg and then adapted tend to converge to nearly the same relative accuracy regardless of adaptation technique.

For our tested hyperparameters, Fair FL training algorithms may harm the relative accuracy distribution for datasets where clients can train high-quality local models by themselves. Therefore, we explore a training methodology intended not to sacrifice accuracy for such clients.

S5.T5.caption: Table 5. FEMNIST performance of the best fair model and our proposed alternative. Despite providing the highest average relative accuracy and the highest amongst the best 10%percent1010\%, the model trained using q=10𝑞10q=10 has more than double the number of underperforming clients of FedAvg (q=0𝑞0q=0). This is also true for TERM with t=1𝑡1t=1. For PaFL, HK​Dsubscript𝐻𝐾𝐷H_{KD} is close to FedAvg while HE​W​Csubscript𝐻𝐸𝑊𝐶H_{EWC} improves the number of underperforming clients for both baseline and adapted models.

references: Having established baselines of accuracy for fair models, we can now evaluate the relative accuracy of FFL, PaFL and their interactions with local adaptation. Unfortunately, the CIFAR-10 data is uninformative as the federated model outperforms the local one for all clients, consistent with the findings of
For q-FFL, the results for the language task showcased in

are less than satisfactory as fair models fail to provide benefits in terms of the number of underperforming clients, relative accuracy, or variance. Furthermore, fair models do not offer an improvement over FedAvg once adapted—this is directly visible in the
scatter plot of relative accuracy against local model accuracy.
The results for image recognition on FEMNIST are more unusual yet similarly discouraging for both q-FFL and TERM.
makes it clear that the fair model achieves a higher relative accuracy on average and amongst the top
of clients at the cost of obtaining a

. Additionally, it has over twice as many underperforming clients with negative relative accuracies. We speculate that focusing on clients with high losses harms the accuracy of fair models on those capable of training high-quality local models. This result is corroborated by the final distribution shown in

the underperforming clients have high local model accuracy. Another factor to consider is the atypical personalisation behaviour of FEMNIST. Models trained with FedAvg and then adapted tend to converge to nearly the same relative accuracy regardless of adaptation technique.

For our tested hyperparameters, Fair FL training algorithms may harm the relative accuracy distribution for datasets where clients can train high-quality local models by themselves. Therefore, we explore a training methodology intended not to sacrifice accuracy for such clients.
